Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: The coordinator emailed a brief suggestion about organizing supplies a different way if time allows.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and I’m sorting canned goods at the food bank, my phone buzzing in my pocket. I know it’s probably Mom or Dad—they always text on weekends, just to check in. I promised I’d keep in touch, especially since I moved out last year. But the volunteer coordinator just sent an email, suggesting we reorganize the supply shelves if we have extra time. I glance at the clock; my shift ends in an hour, and the shelves are a mess. I want to do a good job here, to show I’m reliable and can follow through on suggestions. But my parents expect a reply, even if it’s just a quick “I’m good, love you.” I feel the pressure building—if I stop to text, I’ll lose precious minutes, but if I ignore my parents, I’ll feel guilty for not keeping my promise. My hands hover over my phone, torn between being the dependable son and the committed volunteer, wishing I could be both at once.
